caseTitle: RULES OF PRACTICE OR PROCEDURE [1989-90] VOL XVII RGL 261—27
summary: The case examines the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court of Ghana under rule 66(1) of the Supreme Court Rules, 1970 (CI 13) to waive non-compliance with rule 13(1), which mandates appellants to file a statement of case within three weeks of notification that the record of appeal is ready. In Darke XII v Dei XI, the Supreme Court, by a majority, held that rule 66(1) grants the court jurisdiction to waive non-compliance with rule 13(1) and restore an appeal deemed struck out, interpreting 'action' to include appellate proceedings. However, on the same day, in In re Oppong (Decd), a differently constituted bench held contrarily that rule 66(1) applies only to original jurisdiction matters, thus denying jurisdiction to restore struck-out appeals. The conflicting decisions raise concerns about consistency, with criticism that In re Oppong (Decd) was decided per incuriam, failing to consider the earlier binding decision in Darke XII v Dei XI.
verdict: In Darke XII v Dei XI, the application was dismissed on merits but jurisdiction affirmed; in In re Oppong (Decd), the application was dismissed for lack of jurisdiction.

rationaleHighlights: Rule 66(1) applies to any provision of CI 13, including appellate rules
'Action' includes both original and appellate proceedings
Non-compliance must be non-wilful and in the interests of justice
In re Oppong (Decd) failed to consider binding precedent in Darke XII v Dei XI
Definition of 'party' in rule 70 includes parties to appeals
Jurisdictional conflict between two Supreme Court benches on same day
Per incuriam criticism due to failure to cite prior decision
Use of 'any provisions' in rule 66 supports broad interpretation
